sections.name: intro_1_ambient_establish
sections.reasoning: Energy Match: Energy 25 (LOW 0.0–0.4) fits an intro where the goal is space and anticipation rather than impact; a gentle sweep supports early musical elements (likely light percussion/pads) without demanding attention. Layering Decision: Single template is chosen because low energy sections should default to open/simple and avoid layering overkill ("Less is Often More" + SINGLE template when energy < 0.5). Template Compatibility: N/A (single template) — the point here is clarity and calm. Channel Choices: Shutter=open to match energy <0.5 and preserve strobe budget for later peaks; Color=blue to set a cool, spacious mood and establish palette continuity; Gobo=open to keep a clean readable look and because this is foundational atmosphere (default open gobo 50–60%). Flow: Starts at SOFT_HOME and gently moves toward FORWARD, giving a smooth on-ramp for the next medium-energy verse without a pose jump; keeping the same cool color also avoids early visual churn. Confidence: 5/5 — clean low-energy choice, fully aligned with restraint budgets and sets up the song’s visual language.

sections.name: verse_1_groove_support
sections.reasoning: Energy Match: Energy 55 (MEDIUM 0.5–0.7) suits a verse groove where rhythmic definition increases but vocals still need support rather than spectacle. Layering Decision: Two templates are used because medium energy can benefit from a main movement + accent layer, and this section is long enough to justify added texture without escalating to peak intensity (2-template layering rule for 0.5–0.8). Template Compatibility: Complementary by movement type + plane separation: verse_sweep_pulse provides smooth positional sweep (tilt/overall sweep feel) while ping_pong_chase is dimmer-only motion on static positions; this is "static hold + dynamic movement" and avoids competing large sweeps. Channel Choices: Shutter=pulse (not strobe) because energy is moderate and we want beat reinforcement without spending strobe budget early (pulse budget 10–20% overall); Color stays blue for continuity across multiple sections (color restraint: hold 2–4 sections); Gobo=open to keep readability since we already added a second template layer. Flow: Continues from the intro’s gentle sweep into a more defined verse pulse; end pose moves toward AUDIENCE_CENTER to set up a transition/build that can tighten focus. Confidence: 4/5 — strong groove layering with good restraint; minor compromise is that pulse shutter adds intensity, but it remains within medium-energy rules and preserves strobes for later.

sections.name: transition_1_palette_cleanse
sections.reasoning: Energy Match: Energy 45 sits at the low-medium boundary, ideal for a section boundary where musical phrasing likely shifts (end of verse into a new idea) without needing peak intensity. Layering Decision: Single template because transitions benefit from clean pose changes and clarity (SINGLE template during transitions rule). Template Compatibility: N/A — the transition template already includes fade-through-black repositioning, which should not be visually competed against. Channel Choices: Shutter=open to keep the transition elegant and avoid strobe/pulse fatigue; Color=white marks a major structural boundary (allowed color change at major transitions) and provides a neutral "palette cleanse"; Gobo=open because the transition’s purpose is clarity and repositioning in darkness. Flow: This intentionally breaks the prior groove, resetting to SOFT_HOME so the next build can re-enter with controlled tension; the white color also sets up a more dramatic warm/cool choice later. Confidence: 5/5 — textbook use of a smooth transition with restrained channels and a justified major color shift.

sections.name: build_1_tension_ramp
sections.reasoning: Energy Match: Energy 70 is upper-medium, consistent with a pre-drop build where percussion density and harmonic tension rise. Layering Decision: Two templates because builds often benefit from a foundational motion plus a tension micro-layer to ramp energy without spending strobe budget too early (2-template layering for 0.5–0.8 and build sections). Template Compatibility: Complementary via scale contrast + movement type: tension_mirror_build provides larger accelerating pendulum/sweep arcs, while locked_with_tremble adds high-frequency micro-motion while staying position-locked; this is "large sweeping + small detail" and avoids two big sweeps fighting. Channel Choices: Shutter=pulse (not strobe) because we’re building energy but saving strobe for the actual drop/chorus peaks (shutter rules + strobe restraint); Color stays white to maintain the build’s “tension/neutral” feel and avoid too many color scenes; Gobo=clouds is added because movement is not at maximum speed and the build benefits from atmosphere/texture (gobo allowed when movement is slower/moderate). This also keeps gobo usage limited (we’ll keep gobos off for many other sections). Flow: Comes out of the smooth transition already in white and intensifies motion/tension without a jarring pose jump; ends centered to set up a focused impact template next. Confidence: 4/5 — strong complementary layering; the only caution is adding a gobo during a build, but it’s a moderate-density breakup (clouds) and movement isn’t “fast+complex gobo,” so compatibility is maintained.

sections.name: drop_hit_1_signature_impact
sections.reasoning: Energy Match: Energy 90 (HIGH 0.8–1.0) indicates a true drop/impact moment where the music likely has a strong downbeat transient and sustained high-energy groove. Layering Decision: Single template because this is a signature moment where the template IS the moment; also avoids compounding intensity (single powerful template rule for signature hits). Template Compatibility: N/A — explosive_drop_strobe already contains a hit phase and sustain phase; adding more would risk sensory overload. Channel Choices: Shutter=strobe_medium to honor the drop intensity while managing fatigue (strobe only at peaks; medium rather than fast to reduce overload). Strobe budget check: this section is 8 bars; cumulative strobe so far becomes 8/164 = 4.9%, well under 30%. Color changes to red to mark the major transition into the first peak (allowed at major transition; warm color increases perceived intensity). Gobo=open because the movement is intense and strobing is already complex—per integration rule, keep other channels simple when one is intense (avoid fast movement + complex gobo). Flow: The build ended centered and tense; this snaps into a focused explosive look, then ends FORWARD to open the stage for a longer chorus sustain pattern next. Confidence: 5/5 — perfect peak deployment: strobe reserved for a true high-energy moment, warm color shift signals the drop, and gobo restraint prevents overload.

sections.name: chorus_1_sustain_motion
sections.reasoning: Energy Match: Energy 85 is still high, but more “sustain” than “initial hit,” fitting a chorus where the groove continues and needs hypnotic movement rather than constant impact-only accents. Layering Decision: Two templates because high-energy chorus sections benefit from main movement + accent, and we can create spatial dialogue/texture without resorting to triple-layer complexity (2-template layering for 0.5–0.8+; allowed here because it’s chorus sustain, not a single drop hit). Template Compatibility: Complementary by rhythm offset + movement type: energetic_fan_pulse provides continuous circular/pulsing motion, while sequential_tilt_drop adds occasional left-to-right cascading vertical hits that read as fills on top of the main bed. This is “continuous + punctuated sequential,” avoiding redundancy. Channel Choices: Shutter=open (not strobe) to prevent strobe fatigue after the drop and to keep the chorus readable despite layered movement (rule: avoid strobe→strobe transitions; also keep ONE intense element at a time). Color remains red to hold the same scene across multiple peak sections (color restraint: don’t change every section). Gobo=open because movement is energetic; adding dense gobos would overload. Flow: Smoothly continues from the drop’s red palette but relaxes shutter intensity from strobe to open, giving the audience’s eyes a break while keeping motion energy high; ends centered to set up a potential breakdown/glitch contrast. Confidence: 4/5 — strong restraint choice (open shutter) immediately after a strobe hit; minor compromise is that energy is high yet shutter is open, but this is intentional per strobe budget/fatigue rules.

sections.name: breakdown_1_glitch_contrast
sections.reasoning: Energy Match: Energy 75 is medium-high, appropriate for a breakdown that may reduce melodic density but increases rhythmic/texture interest (glitch/stutter feel). Layering Decision: Two templates because this is a contrast section where complexity can come from texture rather than sheer brightness; layering adds richness without needing strobe. Template Compatibility: Complementary via rhythm offset and movement type: digital_glitch is rapid irregular snap/stutter, while random_bounce is more organic physics-like motion; the contrast between “digital” and “organic” prevents redundancy and creates a layered texture that doesn’t compete in identical timing. Channel Choices: Shutter=pulse to give rhythmic definition without escalating to strobe (energy 0.5–0.7 rule; at 75 it’s slightly above, but within ±0.3 tolerance reasoning: we’re deliberately keeping shutter moderate to preserve strobe budget for the next peak). Color changes to purple to mark a major structural contrast (chorus → breakdown), and to shift mood cooler/edgier without introducing a totally new rainbow scene. Gobo=dots to add a “digital pixel” texture, but we keep shutter at pulse (not strobe) so we don’t stack too many intense elements; dots density is moderate-high but acceptable because the movement is not a sustained fast sweep—it's snap-based where the texture reads. Flow: This deliberately pivots away from the red chorus into a cooler breakdown scene; ending at SOFT_HOME prepares a clean re-build. Confidence: 3/5 — the concept is strong, but it’s a busier visual section (snap texture + gobo). I mitigated by using pulse instead of strobe and by making this the main “textural” gobo moment to stay within gobo budget.

sections.name: build_2_crescendo_to_final_peak
sections.reasoning: Energy Match: Energy 80 indicates a strong build where the music likely reintroduces drive and anticipates a bigger final chorus/climax. Layering Decision: Two templates because this is a long ramp; a reveal/formation layer helps the build feel like it is “assembling” toward the peak (layering for builds). Template Compatibility: Complementary by scale contrast + plane separation: crescendo_sweep_build provides broad sweep acceleration, while chase_from_point is a sequential activation/reveal that reads as structural staging rather than another competing sweep. This is “large sweep + formation reveal,” not “fast+fast.” Channel Choices: Shutter=open (not strobe) despite high build energy to preserve strobe budget for the final peak and to avoid strobe fatigue (strobe reserved for peaks >0.7, but not mandatory; restraint principle). Color stays purple to maintain continuity from breakdown through the build (color restraint: hold 2–4 sections). Gobo=open to reduce visual load because we already used dots in the prior section; also avoids complex gobo with accelerating movement. Flow: Starts from SOFT_HOME (end of breakdown) and progressively tightens to AUDIENCE_CENTER, making the next drop/chorus impact feel earned; keeping purple maintains a coherent “act 2” palette. Confidence: 4/5 — strong build logic and good budget management; slight compromise is using open shutter at energy 80, but it’s justified as a strategic hold-back for the final strobe peak.

sections.name: chorus_2_peak_strobe_moment
sections.reasoning: Energy Match: Energy 95 is the climactic peak tier (HIGH 0.8–1.0), appropriate for the biggest chorus where the song’s maximal density and excitement likely occur. Layering Decision: Single template because this is one of the 1–2 climactic moments where a dedicated peak template should dominate; adding layers risks chaos and reduces readability (single powerful template for signature moments + avoid fast+fast). Template Compatibility: N/A — chorus_circle_strobe already provides sustained hypnotic motion plus strobe. Channel Choices: Shutter=strobe_fast to clearly differentiate this as the biggest peak, while still respecting the strobe budget. Strobe budget check: strobe sections are bars 57–64 (8 bars) + 113–128 (16 bars) = 24 bars strobing; 24/164 = 14.6%, under 30%. Color changes back to red to signal “return to peak” and to complete a simple 3-scene palette (blue intro/verse, white transition/build, red peaks, purple breakdown/build). This is a major transition, so color change is justified and still within ≤5 total changes. Gobo=open to avoid stacking dense texture on top of fast circular motion + fast strobe (integration rule: keep ONE intense, others simple). Flow: The prior build held back on strobe; this release into fast strobe feels earned and maximally impactful. Ending FORWARD opens the look to decrescendo/outro without a hard stop. Confidence: 5/5 — strong climax execution with clean integration and healthy strobe budget remaining.

sections.name: outro_release_and_resolve
sections.reasoning: Energy Match: Energy 35 returns to LOW-MED territory, consistent with an outro where musical elements thin out and the goal is resolution rather than drive. Layering Decision: Two templates are used (rather than single) because the outro is long (36 bars) and benefits from slow evolving depth without increasing intensity; this is a controlled, complementary ambient layering rather than “more energy.” Template Compatibility: Complementary via movement type + scale contrast: pendulum provides gentle organic sway with offsets, while converge_diverge provides slow breathing expansion/contraction; both are slow (not fast+fast) and operate with different motion character (sway vs iris-like expansion), creating texture without competition. Channel Choices: Shutter=open to match energy <0.5 and to give full relief after the peak strobing (avoid strobe fatigue). Color returns to blue to “cool down” emotionally and mirror the intro, creating narrative symmetry; this is a major transition (peak → outro) and remains within the ≤5 color change limit. Gobo=open to keep the outro clean and readable and to keep total gobo usage under 50% of bars. Flow: Smoothly decrescendos from the peak by removing strobe and slowing motion; pose eases back to SOFT_HOME for a final rest state. Confidence: 5/5 — strong release strategy with complementary slow layers and excellent restraint after the climax.

overall_strategy: Overall Strategy: Build a clear 4-scene color narrative with restraint: BLUE (intro/verse calm), WHITE (transition + tension build), RED (drop/chorus peaks), PURPLE (breakdown + rebuild), then back to BLUE for resolution. Movement hierarchy follows the design philosophy: low-energy sections use single ambient templates; medium sections use 2-layer complementary combinations where one layer is structural (sweep/pose) and the other is rhythmic (dimmer chase/pulse) to avoid redundancy. Peak moments are intentionally isolated as single-template signatures with strobe reserved for only the true drops/chorus climax, keeping total strobe well under the 30% fatigue threshold. Gobos are treated as rare texture accents (clouds in build, dots in breakdown) and otherwise kept open to preserve beam readability, especially during fast/high-energy movement. Transitions prioritize clean pose changes (fade-through-black) and avoid abrupt vertical jumps by ending sections in poses that naturally set up the next (SOFT_HOME ↔ FORWARD ↔ AUDIENCE_CENTER).
